title: Japanese Finance Minster: Tokyo Will Review Crypto Tax System ‚Äòby June‚Äô
body: The Japanese Finance Minster Katsunobu Kato has promised Tokyo will review the nation‚Äôs controversial and much-maligned crypto tax laws by the end of June this year. Per the House of Representatives‚Äô official website and a report from the Japanese-language media outlet Iolite , Kato made the comments at a plenary session of the House of Representatives on the 31st. Japanese Finance Minister: Regulators Readying Crypto Tax Review Kato was responding to a question from the Liberal Democratic Party (LDP) lawmaker Akihisa Shiozaki, the head of the party‚Äôs Web3 Digital Society Promotion office. LDP lawmaker Akihisa Shiozaki with a Thai diplomat in October 2023. (Source: MFA of Thailand/X) Kato explained that the Financial Service Agency (FSA) will issue a review ‚Äúbased on the ruling party [LDP]‚Äôs tax system proposals.‚Äù He added that the review would include recommendations on ‚Äúnecessary legislative amendments.‚Äù Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba also waded into the discussion by ‚Äúexpressing his belief that cryptoassets‚Äù would ‚Äúcontribute to solving Japan‚Äôs social problems and improving productivity.‚Äù ‚ÄúThe healthy development of web3 ‚Äì including cryptoassets ‚Äì is extremely important.‚Äù Japanese Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba Ishiba added that it was ‚Äúimportant‚Äù for the government to ‚Äúensure user protection‚Äù and ‚Äúimprove the environment‚Äù of the domestic crypto market. Japan intends to closely monitor the impact on its currency of US President Donald Trump‚Äôs new tariffs and is worried about the international fallout from the trade imposts, Finance Minister Katsunobu Kato said. https://t.co/qxpf4okSOo ‚Äî Bloomberg (@business) February 2, 2025 Regulator‚Äôs Report Key The minister said the FSA will also outline its proposed changes to the nation‚Äôs tax authorities. This, Kato said, will ensure any necessary changes are ‚Äúput in place‚Äù before the new rules roll out. Kato also suggested that Tokyo is ready to change its legal definition of cryptoassets. Existing Japanese law defines crypto as a type of ‚Äúpayment instrument.‚Äù But the minister said that ‚Äúin reality‚Äù coins like Bitcoin (BTC) are ‚Äúmainly traded for investment purposes.‚Äù He added that the FSA has ‚Äúindicated an intention‚Äù to ‚Äútake in a wide range of opinions‚Äù before making an official recommendation ‚Äúon the appropriateness of‚Äù crypto‚Äôs current ‚Äúlegal status.‚Äù Since the FSA began policing the Japanese crypto market in earnest in 2017, the agency has had the last word on all related regulations. The LDP, which has been in power on an almost uninterrupted basis since the 1950s, has formulated basic crypto policy. But it is the FSA that has formulated regulations and legal amendments. Thus far, all of the FSA‚Äôs proposals and requests made to parliament on the matter have been adopted without delay. Trading volumes on the Japanese crypto exchange platform Coincheck over the past 12 months. (Source: CoinGecko) PM‚Äôs Caution Ishiba‚Äôs predecessor Fumio Kishida took a relatively progressive stance on crypto regulation. Ishiba, however, has been more cautious on the matter of tax reform . But he has also made a number of more conciliatory comments about crypto and blockchain. Shiozaki‚Äôs department has called for faster action, claiming late last year that its proposal to reform crypto tax was of ‚Äúurgent‚Äù importance. Japanese tax laws require crypto traders to report their profits on their yearly income tax returns. This runs in contrast to many other countries, which impose flat capital gains levies on traders (at rates of around 20%). Japanese traders must file their crypto trading profits on annual tax returns as ‚Äúother income.‚Äù This means that the wealthiest crypto traders in Japan must hand over up to 55% of their trading profits to the Treasury.
